LanguageData.Edo_paperLanternHanging.label: paper lantern
LanguageData.Edo_paperLanternHanging.description: a paper lantern hanging by a rope
LanguageData.Edo_paperLanternStrung.label: paper lantern strung
LanguageData.Edo_paperLanternStrung.description: paper lanterns strung along a rope
LanguageData.HSSashimono.label: Sashimono
LanguageData.HSSashimono.description: A small banner traditionally worn by foot soliders. This one, however, has been put in place as a colony banner.
LanguageData.HSKatanastand.label: Katana Stand
LanguageData.HSKatanastand.description: A stand for holding and displaying your Katana, a perfect conversation starter at dinner parties.
LanguageData.HSHaka.label: Haka
LanguageData.HSHaka.description: A Haka, or grave. Typically, a Japanese grave is a family grave flowers, incense, and water in front of the monument and a chamber or crypt underneath for the ashes.
LanguageData.HSToriiGate.label: Torii Gate
LanguageData.HSToriiGate.description: Found at the entrance or within a Shinto shrine, it symbolizes the exiting of the material and entering of sacred grounds.
LanguageData.HSHokora.label: Hokora
LanguageData.HSHokora.description: A Hokora acts as a shrine, or home to Minor Kami not claimed by any large shrine.
LanguageData.HSToro.label: Tōrō
LanguageData.HSToro.description: a tōrō is a traditional lantern made of stone, wood, or metal. Like many other elements of Japanese traditional architecture, it originated in China where they can still be found in Buddhist temples and Chinese gardens.
LanguageData.HSHaymat.label: hay mat
LanguageData.HSHaymat.description: A hay mat for sitting, it's not the most comfortable, but there are worse options.
LanguageData.HSRough_Tatami.label: Rough Tatami
LanguageData.HSRough_Tatami.description: A Tatami mat only by the loosest of definitions.
LanguageData.HS_RoughFuton.label: Rough Futon
LanguageData.HS_RoughFuton.description: A roughly made Futon, it's not the prettiest but its way more comfortable then sleeping on the floor.
LanguageData.HS_Chabudai.label: chabudai
LanguageData.HS_Chabudai.description: The chabudai is a short-legged table used in traditional Japanese homes, it ranges from 15-30 Cm and often has collapsible legs for easy storage.
LanguageData.HSFancy_Tatami.label: Fancy Tatami
LanguageData.HSFancy_Tatami.description: An actual tatami mat, fit for a person of status.
LanguageData.HSEdoThrone.label: edo throne
LanguageData.HSEdoThrone.description: 귀족만이 앉을 수 있는 크고 화려한 의자입니다. 왕좌가 배치된 방은 알현실로 지정되며, 귀족의 욕구를 만족시키기 위해 사용됩니다.
LanguageData.HSAndon.label: Andon
LanguageData.HSAndon.description: The andon is a lamp consisting of paper stretched over a frame of bamboo, wood or metal. The paper protects the flame from the wind.
LanguageData.HS_FancyFutonDouble.label: double fancy futon
LanguageData.HS_FancyFutonDouble.description: An ornate futon made large enough for two people.
LanguageData.HS_FancyFuton.label: Fancy Futon
LanguageData.HS_FancyFuton.description: A fancy futon with decorative patterns, fit for a samurai.
LanguageData.HSKoto.label: Koto
LanguageData.HSKoto.description: The average Koto is roughly 180 centimetres (71 in) in length, and features 13 strings, it is also the national instrument of Japan.
LanguageData.HSKamado.label: Kamado
LanguageData.HSKamado.description: A traditional Japanese wood or charcoal-fueled stove, it is designed to steam rice but can be used for cooking other meals like flatbreads.
LanguageData.HSElectricKamado.label: Electric Kamado
LanguageData.HSElectricKamado.description: A traditional Japanese wood or charcoal-fueled stove that's been modified for electric use.
LanguageData.HS_Irori_Small.label: Irori 1x1
LanguageData.HS_Irori_Small.description: A small, simplistic Irori designed for function over form. The Irori is used for heating the home and cooking food.
LanguageData.HS_HaikuSpot.label: Haiku Spot
LanguageData.HS_HaikuSpot.description: A spot for drafting and writing Haiku, trains artistic ability
LanguageData.HSShogiboard.label: shogi board
LanguageData.HSShogiboard.description: A japanese board game that is quite similar to chess, games can last anywhere from half an hour to many hours. Like the chess table, it needs chairs placed adjacent to be usable.
LanguageData.HS_BlackPowderBarrel.label: black powder barrel
LanguageData.HS_BlackPowderBarrel.description: a barrel stuffed full of black powder, great for blowing up unsuspecting raiders. Explodes when damaged.
LanguageData.HS_Shoji_Door.label: 쇼지
LanguageData.HS_Shoji_Door.description: Shoji consists of a thick, translucent paper stretched over a wooden frame that holds together a lattice made of wood or bamboo. Since it is a simple door it must be manually opened, which slows people down. The amount of slowdown depends on what the door is made of.
LanguageData.HSEdo_PlasterWall.label: Shikkui Wall
LanguageData.HSEdo_PlasterWall.description: A plaster wall made from lime and eggshells, as well as a wooden frame.
LanguageData.HSTempleEave.label: Temple Eave
LanguageData.HSDango.label: Dango
LanguageData.HSDango.description: Dango is a Japanese dumpling made from rice flour mixed with uruchi rice flour and glutinous rice flour. Generally Dango is served as a snack with green tea.
LanguageData.HSAdzukiBeanPaste.label: adzuki bean paste
LanguageData.HSAdzukiBeanPaste.description: Adzuki bean paste, or red bean paste, is prepared by boiling the beans, then mashing or grinding them. From there is can be sweetened or left as is.
LanguageData.HSAdzukiDango.label: Adzuki Flavored Dango
LanguageData.HSAdzukiDango.description: Dango is a Japanese dumpling made from rice flour mixed with uruchi rice flour and glutinous rice flour. Generally Dango is served as a snack with green tea. This kind is flavored with Aduzki bean paste
LanguageData.HSKoku.label: Koku
LanguageData.HSKoku.description: A Koku is a bundle that contains enough rice to feed a person for roughly a year, and is a source of currency in edo japan. In rimworld terms, however, it is only 75 units of rice, as the actual amount required to feed a pawn per year would be roughly 1,920 units of rice. Koku can be unbundled at a crafting spot or cooking station.
LanguageData.hs_Edo_Bamboo.label: 대나무
LanguageData.hs_Edo_Bamboo.description: bamboo from... bamboo, its flexible and fast growing, while not as strong as some woods it is very good for load bearing and wind resistance, bamboo also tends to be more fire resistant then wood.
LanguageData.hs_Edo_Bamboo.tools.0.label: 목재
LanguageData.HSUnfinishedHaybase.label: unfinished Hay item
LanguageData.HSApparel_Roningasa.label: Roningasa
LanguageData.HSApparel_Roningasa.description: A Roningasa, it helps keep the sun out of your eyes.
LanguageData.HSApparel_Hitaiate.label: Hitai-Ate
LanguageData.HSApparel_Hitaiate.description: A forehead protector made with a strip of cloth and a metal plate layered over.
LanguageData.HSApparel_Amigasa.label: Amigasa
LanguageData.HSApparel_Amigasa.description: An Amigasa, it helps keep the sun out of your eyes.
LanguageData.HSApparel_Menpo.label: Menpo
LanguageData.HSApparel_Menpo.description: A face mask that helps secure top-heavy Kabuto, its fashioned to look like the face of a demon, and gives off an air of authority.
LanguageData.HSApparel_Tengai.label: Tengai
LanguageData.HSApparel_Tengai.description: Tengai are often worn by Komusō monks,they symbolize a dismissal of ego or self.
LanguageData.HSApparel_Soheiheadwrap.label: Sohei Headwrap
LanguageData.HSApparel_Soheiheadwrap.description: A Headwrap worn by the Sohei Warrior Monks.
LanguageData.HSApparel_SamuraiFaceGuard.label: Faceguard
LanguageData.HSApparel_SamuraiFaceGuard.description: this face guard doesn't offer much protection, but it's cheaper to make than a menpo and better then nothing.
LanguageData.HSApparel_Hachimaki.label: Hachimaki
LanguageData.HSApparel_Hachimaki.description: A headband typically made of red or white cloth and featuring an inspirational slogan. It provides little armor but gives a sort of bravado.
LanguageData.HSKabuto.label: Kabuto
LanguageData.HSKabuto.description: A Zunari Kabuto. It is an important part of the samurais equipment, provided they wish to keep their heads.
LanguageData.HSBoldKabuto.label: Bold Kabuto
LanguageData.HSBoldKabuto.description: A Zunari Kabuto adorned with deer horns. This ornament is a challenge more than a fashion choice, a bold statement on the battlefield that says "Here I am, try and take me".
LanguageData.HSKenseiKabuto.label: Kensei Kabuto
LanguageData.HSKenseiKabuto.description: A Zunari Kabuto given to sword saints. Those who wear this helmet know this well; The flow of battle may change in but a moment, hesitation is defeat.
LanguageData.HSDaimyoKabuto.label: Daimyo's Kabuto
LanguageData.HSDaimyoKabuto.description: A beautifully crafted Kabuto, it's golden visage makes the presence of a Daimyo obvious, inspiring nearby allies to fight and work harder. (Requires Ideology to gain special hediff)
LanguageData.HSVetereanKabuto.label: Veterans Kabuto
LanguageData.HSVetereanKabuto.description: A heavy kabuto, while its sheer weight may slow you down, it'll keep your head intact.
LanguageData.HSPrestigeKabuto.label: Prestige Kabuto
LanguageData.HSPrestigeKabuto.description: A Kabuto that is more labor intensive then your standard kabuto. The extra effort pays off in the form of a tougher helmet.
LanguageData.HSApparel_ShinobiHalfmask.label: Shinobi Halfmask
LanguageData.HSApparel_ShinobiHalfmask.description: A halfmask used to keep ones face hidden.
LanguageData.HSApparel_HannyaMask.label: Hannya mask
LanguageData.HSApparel_HannyaMask.description: A face mask used in Noh theater, it is designed to repersent a jealous feminine demon. It is also a good choice for shinobi seeking to conceal their faces.
LanguageData.HSApparel_WorkersHeadband.label: Workers Headband
LanguageData.HSApparel_WorkersHeadband.description: A headband worn by the working class of feudal Japan, it helps keep your hair and sweat out of your eyes.
LanguageData.HSApparel_ChildKimono.label: Child's Kimono
LanguageData.HSApparel_ChildKimono.description: A traditional Kimono made for children.
LanguageData.HSApparel_ChildStrawcloak.label: Child's Strawcloak
LanguageData.HSApparel_ChildStrawcloak.description: A Strawcloak for children, good for keeping dry.
LanguageData.HSApparel_Kimono.label: Kimono
LanguageData.HSApparel_Strawcloak.label: Strawcloak
LanguageData.HSApparel_Strawcloak.description: A Strawcloak, good for keeping dry.
LanguageData.HSApparel_Hakama.label: Hakama
LanguageData.HSApparel_Kataginu.label: Kataginu
LanguageData.HSApparel_Kataginu.description: A Kataginu, work with a Hakama to form a kamishimo.
LanguageData.HSApparel_Do.label: Dō
LanguageData.HSApparel_Do.description: The Dō, also known as Dou or Dō-maru, is the protective breastplate worn by both Ashigaru and Samurai.
LanguageData.HSApparel_Hanten.label: 해턴
LanguageData.HSApparel_Hanten.description: The Hanten is a coat made for cold weather, it bears resemblance to the Haori and is worn by both man and woman.
LanguageData.HSApparel_Haori.label: Haori
LanguageData.HSApparel_Haori.description: The Haori is a traditonal jacket that resembles a shortened Kimono, it typically features a thinner collar and was seen as a symbol of wealth and power.
LanguageData.HSApparel_Tatami.label: Tatami Armor
LanguageData.HSApparel_Tatami.description: Tatami was a lightweight portable folding armor, it was used by both samurai and ashigaru, although it was more common among ashigaru since it was cheaper and easier to make.
LanguageData.HSApparel_HeavyDo.label: heavy dō
LanguageData.HSApparel_HeavyDo.description: The Dō, also known as Dou or Dō-maru, is the protective breastplate worn by both Ashigaru and Samurai. This is a very heavy variant of the armor, sacrificing mobility for defense.
LanguageData.HS_DaikyuBasic.label: daikyū
LanguageData.HS_DaikyuBasic.description: the daikyū is a longer version of the japanese yumi bow.
LanguageData.HS_DaikyuBasic.tools.0.label: 활대
LanguageData.HSDaikyu_Ya.label: Daikyu Ya
LanguageData.HSTanegashimaRifle.label: Tanegashima Rifle
LanguageData.HSTanegashimaRifle.description: Tanegashima rifles were introduced halfway into the Sengoku period, their armor piercing capabilities helped bring about the end of traditional heavily armored samurai.
LanguageData.HSTanegashimaRifle.tools.0.label: 개머리판
LanguageData.HSTanegashimaRifle.tools.1.label: 총열
LanguageData.HSTanegashima_Leadball.label: 납탄
LanguageData.HSTanegashimaPistol.label: Tanegashima Pistol
LanguageData.HSTanegashimaPistol.description: While it lacks the range of Tangeshima rifle, it is much more versatile in close range combat, its quicker to reload too.
LanguageData.HSTanegashimaPistol.tools.0.label: 개머리판
LanguageData.HSTanegashimaPistol.tools.1.label: 총열
LanguageData.HS_Kunai.label: Kunai
LanguageData.HS_Kunai.description: Originally made as a masoonry trowel, the Kunai is a multi-use knife like weapon. It can be used as a throwing knife, for slashing, or even be tied to a rope and used as a harpoon. These Kunai are just as lethal in melee combat as they are in ranged.
LanguageData.HS_Kunai.tools.0.label: 손잡이
LanguageData.HS_Kunai.tools.1.label: 날
LanguageData.HS_Kunai.tools.2.label: 끝
LanguageData.HS_Thrown_Kunai.label: Kunai
LanguageData.HS_Edo_Blackpowder_Bomb.label: Blackpowder bomb
LanguageData.HS_Edo_Blackpowder_Bomb.description: An early variation of a grenade, the blackpowder bomb isn't as effective as an industrial grade grenade, but it can get the job done.
LanguageData.HS_Edo_Blackpowder_Bomb.verbs.0.label: throw blackpowder bomb
LanguageData.Proj_BlackpowderBomb.label: Blackpowder Bomb
LanguageData.HS_BasicKama.label: kama
LanguageData.HS_BasicKama.description: a traditional Japanese farming tool. It's sharp tip is good for puncturing armor and the blade is as good at hacking apart limbs as it is weeds.
LanguageData.HS_BasicKama.tools.0.label: 손잡이
LanguageData.HS_BasicKama.tools.1.label: 발톱 끝
LanguageData.HS_BasicKama.tools.2.label: 날
LanguageData.HS_BasicMasakari.label: masakari
LanguageData.HS_BasicMasakari.description: the masakari, or ono, is an often overlooked weapon in the samurai's arsenal. this beast was able to hew both armor and building alike.
LanguageData.HS_BasicMasakari.tools.0.label: 자루
LanguageData.HS_BasicMasakari.tools.1.label: 날
LanguageData.HS_BasicKanabo.label: kanabo
LanguageData.HS_BasicKanabo.description: The Kanabo is a spiked or studded two-handed war club used in feudal Japan. It's an age old solution to armor: hit them with something bigger and heavier.
LanguageData.HS_BasicKanabo.tools.0.label: 자루
LanguageData.HS_BasicKanabo.tools.1.label: 머리
LanguageData.HS_BasicNagamaki.label: nagamaki
LanguageData.HS_BasicNagamaki.description: the nagamaki could be seen as something of a fusion between a naginata and a katana. the weapon could be two feet or taller and would be equal parts hilt and blade.
LanguageData.HS_BasicNagamaki.tools.0.label: 자루
LanguageData.HS_BasicNagamaki.tools.1.label: 끝
LanguageData.HS_BasicNagamaki.tools.2.label: 날
LanguageData.HS_BasicKatana.label: 카타나
LanguageData.HS_BasicKatana.description: A basic katana, a side arm of every samurai.
LanguageData.HS_BasicKatana.tools.0.label: 자루
LanguageData.HS_BasicKatana.tools.1.label: 끝
LanguageData.HS_BasicKatana.tools.2.label: 날
LanguageData.HS_BasicNaginata.label: naginata
LanguageData.HS_BasicNaginata.description: The naginata is a pole arm with the blade of a katana attached at the end, it is most often depicted as being used by Onna-bushi.
LanguageData.HS_BasicNaginata.tools.0.label: 자루
LanguageData.HS_BasicNaginata.tools.1.label: 끝
LanguageData.HS_BasicNaginata.tools.2.label: 날
LanguageData.HS_BasicOdachi.label: odachi
LanguageData.HS_BasicOdachi.description: To qualify as an ōdachi a blade must have the length of around 3 shaku, it is so large that one possible use of ōdachi is as an anti-cavalry weapons, to strike down the horse as it approaches.
LanguageData.HS_BasicOdachi.tools.0.label: 자루
LanguageData.HS_BasicOdachi.tools.1.label: 끝
LanguageData.HS_BasicOdachi.tools.2.label: 날
LanguageData.HS_BasicYari.label: yari
LanguageData.HS_BasicYari.description: Yari is the term for a traditionally-made Japanese blade in the form of a spear, early yari are believed to have been derived from Chinese spears.
LanguageData.HS_BasicYari.tools.0.label: 자루
LanguageData.HS_BasicYari.tools.1.label: 끝
LanguageData.HS_BasicYari.tools.2.label: 날
LanguageData.HS_Bokken.label: bokken
LanguageData.HS_Bokken.description: the bokken is a wooden weapon, while often shaped like the katana it can be shaped to look like any weapon. It is primarily used for training, but can still be used to kill or harm. The blunt nature of it makes it ideal for taking prisoners.
LanguageData.HS_Bokken.tools.0.label: 자루
LanguageData.HS_Bokken.tools.1.label: 끝
LanguageData.HS_Bokken.tools.2.label: 날
LanguageData.HS_BasicTanto.label: Tantō
LanguageData.HS_BasicTanto.description: The Tanto is a small dagger like weapon, its small and light nature makes it ideal for exploiting weakspots in armor. During the Edo period Samurai were required to wear the Katana with a shorter weapon, like a Tanto or Wakizashi. This pairing was called a Daisho
LanguageData.HS_BasicTanto.tools.0.label: 자루
LanguageData.HS_BasicTanto.tools.1.label: 끝
LanguageData.HS_BasicTanto.tools.2.label: 날
LanguageData.HS_BasicWakizashi.label: Wakizashi
LanguageData.HS_BasicWakizashi.description: Shorter then the Katana, the Wakizashi is often between 30 and 60 cm (12 and 24 in), the shorter size is fit for combat in doors, and was a more popular choice for the mandated Daisho pairing during the Edo Period.
LanguageData.HS_BasicWakizashi.tools.0.label: 자루
LanguageData.HS_BasicWakizashi.tools.1.label: 끝
LanguageData.HS_BasicWakizashi.tools.2.label: 날
LanguageData.HS_ClanforgedKatana.label: clanforged katana
LanguageData.HS_ClanforgedKatana.description: An artisanal Katana, built with both form and function in mind.
LanguageData.HS_ClanforgedKatana.tools.0.label: 자루
LanguageData.HS_ClanforgedKatana.tools.1.label: 끝
LanguageData.HS_ClanforgedKatana.tools.2.label: 날
LanguageData.HS_ClanforgedNaginata.label: clanforged naginata
LanguageData.HS_ClanforgedNaginata.description: An artisanal Naginata, built with both form and function in mind.
LanguageData.HS_ClanforgedNaginata.tools.0.label: 자루
LanguageData.HS_ClanforgedNaginata.tools.1.label: 끝
LanguageData.HS_ClanforgedNaginata.tools.2.label: 날
LanguageData.HS_ClanforgedYari.label: clanforged yari
LanguageData.HS_ClanforgedYari.description: An artisanal Yari, built with both form and function in mind.
LanguageData.HS_ClanforgedYari.tools.0.label: 자루
LanguageData.HS_ClanforgedYari.tools.1.label: 끝
LanguageData.HS_ClanforgedYari.tools.2.label: 날
LanguageData.HS_ClanforgedOdachi.label: clanforged odachi
LanguageData.HS_ClanforgedOdachi.description: An artisanal Odachi, built with both form and function in mind.
LanguageData.HS_ClanforgedOdachi.tools.0.label: 자루
LanguageData.HS_ClanforgedOdachi.tools.1.label: 끝
LanguageData.HS_ClanforgedOdachi.tools.2.label: 날
LanguageData.HS_ClanForgedNagamaki.label: clanforged nagamaki
LanguageData.HS_ClanForgedNagamaki.description: An artisanal Nagamaki, built with both form and function in mind.
LanguageData.HS_ClanForgedNagamaki.tools.0.label: 자루
LanguageData.HS_ClanForgedNagamaki.tools.1.label: 끝
LanguageData.HS_ClanForgedNagamaki.tools.2.label: 날
LanguageData.HS_RoninKatana.label: ronin's katana
LanguageData.HS_RoninKatana.description: An aged Katana bearing the faded symbol of a long forgotten clan, despite its age the blade is so sharp that it can rend through armor.
LanguageData.HS_RoninKatana.tools.0.label: 자루
LanguageData.HS_RoninKatana.tools.1.label: 끝
LanguageData.HS_RoninKatana.tools.2.label: 날
LanguageData.HS_LegendaryKatana.label: Legendary Katana
LanguageData.HS_LegendaryKatana.description: An exquisitely crafted blade with a rich history of legends.
LanguageData.HS_LegendaryKatana.tools.0.label: 손잡이
LanguageData.HS_LegendaryKatana.tools.1.label: 끝
LanguageData.HS_LegendaryKatana.tools.2.label: 날
LanguageData.HS_Tenbinbo.label: tenbinbō
LanguageData.HS_Tenbinbo.description: The tenbinbō is made of two wooden containers hanging on a stick, it is used for hauling resources such as food or water.
LanguageData.HS_Straw_Backpack.label: Straw Backpack
LanguageData.HS_Straw_Backpack.description: A straw backpack used for hauling items.
LanguageData.HSPlant_TallBambooTree.label: tall bamboo tree
LanguageData.HSPlant_TallBambooTree.description: A taller variant of bamboo trees, while it takes slightly longer to reach its full height the wood yield is much better.
LanguageData.HSPlant_SusukiGrass.label: susuki grass
LanguageData.HSPlant_SusukiGrass.description: 키가 큰 야생의 잡초입니다. 이동하는 사람의 속도가 느려집니다.
LanguageData.HSPlant_SingleBambooTree.label: bamboo stalk
LanguageData.HSPlant_SingleBambooTree.description: A single stalk of tall bamboo, it doesn't yield as much wood as clusters of tall bamboo will, but it does grow a little quicker.
LanguageData.HSPlant_GroveBush.label: grove bush
LanguageData.HSPlant_GroveBush.description: 짧은 관목입니다. 보통 말을 하진 않습니다.
LanguageData.HSPlant_ForestGroundCover.label: grove groundcover
LanguageData.HSPlant_ForestGroundCover.description: an assortment of wild bamboo grove groundcovers.
LanguageData.HSPlant_VioletGroveFlower.label: Violet Flower
LanguageData.HSPlant_VioletGroveFlower.description: A cluster of Violet flowers native to bamboo groves.
LanguageData.Plant_TreeBamboo.label: 대나무
LanguageData.Plant_TreeBamboo.description: 생물학적으로 나무가 아니지만, 인식적으로는 나무로 분류되는 식물. 키가 크고 빠르게 자라납니다.
LanguageData.HSPlant_Adzuki.label: Adzuki bean plant
LanguageData.HSPlant_Adzuki.description: A bean plant that yields Adzuki beans, also called red beans, they can be mashed up into a sweet paste.
